00040 #ifndef _physeventmanager_h
00041 #define _physeventmanager_h
00042 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00043 //This will capture all event and store them for easy dispatching.
00044 //There will be an instance of this class in the world.
00045 ///////////////////////////////////////
00046 
00047 #include <list>
00048 #include <queue>
00049 
00050 using namespace std;
00051 
00052 #include "eventbase.h"
00053 #include "eventrendertime.h"
00054 #include "eventuserinput.h"
00055 #include "eventquit.h"
00056 
00057 namespace phys
00058 {
00059     class World;
00060 
00061     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00062     /// @class EventManager
00063     /// @headerfile eventmanager.h
00064     /// @brief This is a container for Events and facilitates the transfer of data.
00065     /// @details The Event Manager Exists to passed important information about
00066     /// Gamestate from where it is generated to where it is needed. It is the Game
00067     /// Developers option whether they want to grab events directly using the get
00068     /// functions that have filters, or if they want to get all the events at once
00069     /// from a central location and dispatch form there. \n
00070     /// Since all User input comes in the form of events, this is also where user
00071     /// input Polling and optional input sources like Joysticks are controlled
00072     /// from. \n
00073     /// All of these event are stored in an internal Queue and order is preserved.
00074     /// So the First item In will be the First Out (FIFO). This is not strictly a
00075     /// FIFO buffer, there are a number of functions for getting of managing
00076     /// specific kinds of events. Generally these 'Filtered' management functions
00077     /// Still return the first of those kinds of event.
00078     /// @warning Delete pointers you get from this. Anything can create events and
00079     /// Put them here, and anything can get them out, This means the simple way to
00080     /// not cause memory leaks is to have the routines extracting the events delete
00081     /// the events.
00082     /// @warning Currently this is not thread safe, even though it should be.
00083     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00084     class EventManager
00085     {
00086         private:
00087             //The Default Physics worlds that this Eventmanager is expected to interact with
00088             World* ParentWorld;
00089 
00090             //The Queue that all the events get stored in
00091             std::list<EventBase*> EventQueue;
00092 
00093             //Checks for quit messages and adds them to the queue
00094             void UpdateQuitEvents();
00095 
00096             // A list of the Mouse buttons being watched
00097             vector<int> WatchMouseKeys;
00098 
00099             //a List of the Keyboard keys being watch
00100             vector<MetaCode::InputCode> WatchKeyboardKeys;
00101 
00102             //These are use to decide if mouse location should be polled.
00103             bool PollMouseHor;
00104             bool PollMouseVert;
00105 
00106             //These does the heavy lifting during the polling operation
00107             //All of these poll the input subsystem and add MetaCodes to the vector they are passed.
00108             void PollKeyboard(vector<MetaCode> &CodeBag);
00109             void PollMouseButtons(vector<MetaCode> &CodeBag);
00110             void PollMouseLocation(vector<MetaCode> &CodeBag);
00111 
00112             //SDL event specific Items
00113             //This function will get all the events from SDL and Sort them into one of two Queues
00114             void PreProcessSDLEvents();
00115             queue<RawEvent*> SDL_WmEvents;
00116             queue<RawEvent*> SDL_UserInputEvents;
00117 
00118         public:
00119             /// @todo TODO build a deconstructor that deletes all the events still in the queue
00120 
00121             /// @brief Default constructor
00122             /// @param ParentWorld_ A pointer to the world that this world is working with Primarily
00123             /// @details This creates an empty PhysEventManger
00124             EventManager(World* ParentWorld_);
00125 
00126         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00127         // Management functions - Work with all events
00128         ///////////////////////////////////////
00129             /// @brief Gets a count of events
00130             /// @details This returns a total count of all events stored in this PhysEventManager.
00131             /// @return This returns an unsigned integer with the amount of of total events
00132             unsigned int GetRemainingEventCount();
00133 
00134             /// @brief Return a pointer to the Next event
00135             /// @details This returns a pointer to the next PhysEvent. It is advisable to use this for performance reasons
00136             /// because it runs in constant time. However it does not return a specific kind of event, and must be cast
00137             /// in order to use the true content. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no events in the que.
00138             /// @return A pointer to a PhysEvent, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00139             EventBase* GetNextEvent();
00140 
00141             /// @brief Return a pointer to the Next event, and removes the Event from storage
00142             /// @details This functions just like GetNextEvent , except that it also removes the item from the internal storage
00143             /// of the PhysEventManager. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no events in the que.
00144             /// @return A pointer to a PhysEvent, that will need to be deleted once it has been used.
00145             EventBase* PopNextEvent();
00146 
00147             /// @brief Removes an Event From the que without looking at it.
00148             /// @details This together with GetNextEvent() are the same as call PopNextEvent().
00149             /// @warning If you did not call GetNextEvent() and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with this pointer, then this is a memory leak.
00150             /// Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately
00151             /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a que could. Any with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00152             void RemoveNextEvent();
00153 
00154             /// @brief Adds an event of any kind to the end of the Event Queue
00155             /// @param EventToAdd This is a pointer to an Event.
00156             /// @details This adds the existing event to the Queue. Be careful this is not delete, and does not go out of scope. Deleting the Event is now the
00157             /// responsibilty of the code that pulls it out of Event Manager.
00158             void AddEvent(EventBase* EventToAdd);
00159 
00160             /// @brief Pulls Events from the all the subsystems for use in the EventManager.
00161             /// @details The work this function does is already performed in the main loop. This only really needs to be used
00162             /// If a game developer chooses to use his own main loop and does't use UpdateSystemEvents() or UpdateUserInputEvents()
00163             void UpdateEvents();
00164 
00165             /// @brief Pulls System and Window manager Events from the all the subsystems for use in the EventManager.
00166             /// @details This adds events, like EventQuit and Other Windows manager events. The work this function does is already performed
00167             /// in the main loop. This only really needs to be used If a game developer chooses to use his own main loop and does't use UpdateEvents()
00168             /// and plans on using UpdateUserInputEvents()
00169             void UpdateSystemEvents();
00170 
00171             /// @brief Pulls User Interface Events from the all the subsystems for use in the EventManager.
00172             /// @details This adds events, like EventUserInput to the eventmanager. The work this function does is already performed
00173             /// in the main loop. This only really needs to be used If a game developer chooses to use his own main loop and does't use UpdateEvents()
00174             /// and plans on using UpdateSystemEvents()
00175             void UpdateUserInputEvents();
00176 
00177             /// @brief This returns a complete list of all events in the event manager
00178             /// @details This simply returns a const pointer of the internal event queue.
00179             /// @warning The pointers contained in this list must be used carefully. Do not delete them, this will cause errors.
00180             /// @return This returns a const pointer the list<EventBase*> which is this classes event pointer list. Use this carefully, even though it is a const pointer it is still possible to mess around with internals in an innapropriate way. Treat this as if it were read only.
00181             const std::list<EventBase*>* GetAllEvents() const;
00182 
00183         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00184         // Filtered management functions - RenderTime Events
00185         ///////////////////////////////////////
00186             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next Rendertime event
00187             /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next Rendertime event. It is inadvisable to use
00188             /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00189             /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no rendertime
00190             /// events in the que.
00191             /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventRenderTime, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00192             EventRenderTime* GetNextRenderTimeEvent();
00193 
00194             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next Rendertime event and removes it from the Que
00195             /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next Rendertime event. It is inadvisable to use
00196             /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00197             /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no rendertime
00198             /// events in the que. This also removes the returned pointer form the Que.
00199             /// @return A pointer to a PhysEventRenderTime, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00200             EventRenderTime* PopNextRenderTimeEvent();
00201 
00202             /// @brief Removes the First Rendertime Event From the que without looking at it.
00203             /// @details This together with GetNextRenderTimeEvent() are the pretty much same as call PopNextRenderTimeEvent().
00204             /// @warning If you did not call GetNextRenderTimeEvent() and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with this pointer, then this is a memory leak.
00205             /// Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately
00206             /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a queue could. And with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00207             void RemoveNextRenderTimeEvent();
00208 
00209             /// @brief This returns a complete list of all the Render Time events.
00210             /// @details This finds all the EventUserInput Events then creates a new list and returns that. This runs in linear time relative to the amounts of events.
00211             /// @return This returns a list<EventRenderTime*> pointer which is this a subset of this classes event pointer list. Use this carefully, it can cause errors if used improperly. Additionally this list pointer must be deleted, but not the events in it.
00212             std::list<EventRenderTime*>* GetAllRenderTimeEvents();
00213 
00214         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00215         // Filtered management functions - User Input Events
00216         ///////////////////////////////////////
00217             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next User Input event
00218             /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next User Input event. It is inadvisable to use
00219             /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00220             /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no User Input
00221             /// events in the que.
00222             /// @return A pointer to a EventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00223             EventUserInput* GetNextUserInputEvent();
00224 
00225             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next User Input event and removes it from the Que
00226             /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next User Input event. It is inadvisable to use
00227             /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00228             /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no User Input
00229             /// events in the que. This also removes the returned pointer form the Que.
00230             /// @return A pointer to a EventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00231             EventUserInput* PopNextUserInputEvent();
00232 
00233             /// @brief Removes the First User Input Event From the que without looking at it.
00234             /// @details This together with GetNextUserInputEvent() are the pretty much same as call PopNextUserInputEvent().
00235             /// @warning If you did not call GetNextUserInputEvent() and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with this pointer, then this is a memory leak.
00236             /// Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately
00237             /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a queue could. And with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00238             void RemoveNextUserInputEvent();
00239 
00240             /// @brief This returns a complete list of all the User Input events.
00241             /// @details This finds all the EventUserInput Events then creates a new list and returns that. This runs in linear time relative to the amounts of events.
00242             /// @return This returns a std::list<EventUserInput*> pointer which is this a subset of this classes event pointer list. Use this carefully, it can cause errors if used improperly. Additionally this list pointer must be deleted, but not the events in it.
00243             std::list<EventUserInput*>* GetAllUserInputEvents();
00244 
00245         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00246         // Filtered management functions - Quit Events
00247         ///////////////////////////////////////
00248             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next EventQuit
00249             /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next EventQuit. It is inadvisable to use
00250             /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00251             /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no EventQuit
00252             /// events in the que.
00253             /// @return A pointer to a EventQuit, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00254             EventQuit* GetNextQuitEvent();
00255 
00256             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next EventQuit and removes it from the Que.
00257             /// @details This Filtered event management function returns a pointer to the next EventQuit. It is inadvisable to use
00258             /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events. However, it will return an immediately
00259             /// usable pointer for case where an extreme level of performance is not required. This returns a pointer to 0 if there are no EventQuit
00260             /// events in the que. This also removes the returned pointer form the Que.
00261             /// @return A pointer to a EventQuit, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00262             EventQuit* PopNextQuitEvent();
00263 
00264             /// @brief Removes the First EventQuit From the que without looking at it.
00265             /// @details This together with GetNextQuitEvent() are the pretty much same as call PopNextQuitEvent().
00266             /// @warning If you did not call GetNextQuitEvent() and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with this pointer, then this is a memory leak.
00267             /// Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately
00268             /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a queue could. And with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00269             void RemoveNextQuitEvent();
00270 
00271             /// @brief This returns a complete list of all the quit events.
00272             /// @details This finds all the EventQuit Events then creates a new list and returns that. This runs in linear time relative to the amounts of events.
00273             /// @warning Something is wrong if you have more than a few quit events. These should be checked for in each iteration of the main loop.
00274             /// @return This returns a std::list<EventQuit*> pointer which is this a subset of this classes event pointer list. Use this carefully, it can cause errors if used improperly. Additionally this list pointer must be deleted, but not the events in it.
00275             std::list<EventQuit*>* GetAllQuitEvents();
00276 
00277         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00278         // Filtered management functions - You choose YAYYYY!!!
00279         ///////////////////////////////////////
00280             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next kind event of the Specified type
00281             /// @param SpecificType This is a PhysEvent::EventType that defines the type you want this to work with
00282             /// @details This and the other NextSpecificEvent functions are the core of the Event Filtering System. In general the other filtering
00283             /// functions call one of these and does very little work on their own. \n This performs a linear search starting with the oldest (first entered
00284             /// Events) and simply checks if it the of the correct type. Then this returns a pointer to the next event of the specified type, or returns
00285             /// a pointer to 0 if there are none of the correct pointers in the Que. It is inadvisable to use
00286             /// this for performance reasons becuase it runs in linear time relative to the amount of events.
00287             /// @return A pointer to a EventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00288             EventBase* GetNextSpecificEvent(EventBase::EventType SpecificType);
00289 
00290             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next kind event of the Specified type, and removes it from the Que
00291             /// @param SpecificType This is a PhysEvent::EventType that defines the type you want this to work with
00292             /// @details This is just like GetNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType) but it also removes the item from the Que.
00293             /// @return A pointer to a EventUserInput, that still needs to be removed from the event manager and deleted.
00294             EventBase* PopNextSpecificEvent(EventBase::EventType SpecificType);
00295 
00296             /// @brief Returns a pointer to the Next kind event of the Specified type, and removes it from the Que
00297             /// @param SpecificType This is a PhysEvent::EventType that defines the type you want this to work with
00298             /// @details This is just like PopNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType) but exept it doesn't bother with any of the needed
00299             /// structure involved with returning data, and just removes the specific event from the Queue.
00300             /// @warning If you did not call GetNextSpecificEvent(PhysEvent::EventType SpecificType) and haven't deleted or stored, or somehow dealt with
00301             /// this pointer, then this is a memory leak. Don't use this unless you are certain you have taken care of the pointer appropriately.
00302             /// @exception This can throw any STL exception a queue could. And with likely throw some kind of except if called when there are no Events in the Que.
00303             void RemoveNextSpecificEvent(EventBase::EventType SpecificType);
00304 
00305             /// @brief This returns a complete list of all the specified events.
00306             /// @details This finds all the events that are of the specified type in the event manager, then creates a new list
00307             /// and return that. This runs in linear time relative to the amounts of events.
00308             /// @warning The pointers contained in this list must be used carefully. Do not delete them, this will cause errors.
00309             /// @return This returns a std::list<EventBase*> pointer which is this a subset of this classes event pointer list. Use this carefully, it can cause errors if used improperly. Additionally this list pointer must be deleted, but not the events in it.
00310             std::list<EventBase*>* GetAllSpecificEvents(EventBase::EventType SpecificType);
00311 
00312             /// @brief This removes all the events of the specified type.
00313             /// @details This finds all the events that are of the specified type in the event manager, then removes them.
00314             /// @warning This does not delete the events. This is a memory leak unless used with GetAllSpecificEvents so that the events can be tracked indeendantly, and deleted.
00315             void RemoveAllSpecificEvents(EventBase::EventType SpecificType);
00316 
00317         ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00318         // Polling management functions
00319         ///////////////////////////////////////
00320             /// @brief Generates extra events each iteration of the main loop, based on user input polling
00321             /// @param InputToTryPolling This accepts a MetaCode and will try to watch for occurences like this one
00322             /// @details This will trigger the input system to generate an event (or add to an exiting event) when polling for the given kind of event. Each
00323             /// Iteration of the main loop there will be a EventUserInput that created. That Event will Include all the normal metacodes for user input
00324             /// that happened, and it will also have a meta code for each time this function was called. The added metacode may be partialky ignored, the
00325             /// Metavalue is almost always ignored, and in a situation where the can only be one of a given input on a system, the ID is ignore and 0 is assumed.
00326             /// @exception "Unsupported Polling Check on this Platform" When the metacode passed cannot be polled on this platform
00327             void AddPollingCheck(const MetaCode &InputToTryPolling);
00328 
00329             /// @brief Removes Events from the list(s) of what needs to be polled
00330             /// @param InputToStopPolling This accepts a MetaCode and will try to Remove Watches like this one
00331             /// @details This will remove any check for polling that share the same inputcode and ID. This
00332             /// @exception "Polling check not present" Is thrown
00333             void RemovePollingCheck(const MetaCode &InputToStopPolling);
00334 
00335             /// @brief This activates the polling routines of the user input subsystems
00336             /// @details This checks the current state of user input devices that have been added by AddPollingCheck(const MetaCode &InputToTryPolling).
00337             /// This is called automatically by main loop processing, but there is no harm in calling it several times.
00338             /// @return This returns a pointer to a EventUserInput that contains the desired metacodes
00339             EventUserInput* PollForUserInputEvents();
00340     };
00341 }
00342 #endif
